I work in a hospital with patients so I cant have any contact until I am sure that I can handle moving people and machines. lol. I feel like I didnt heal as fast as most on this board probably do to the fact that I wasnt in as great a shape before hand. The thought of running 5 miles a day hasnt entered my mind in many many moons. However after a week or 2 when I started getting off of the pain meds and doing physical therapy I wanted to do things that I wasnt allowed to do. I would wait for my warden (daughter) to go to work then I would clean and work in the yard and lift things I shouldnt and then cry all night cause I was in pain later that day. They have specific guidelines for what you are allowed to do post surgery by however many weeks. I was told not to lift more than 3 lbs. what a joke... Just listen to your body. A good stretch is ok but when it gets to pain you should stop. My surgeon would always tell me to not mess up her work. lol. I had numbness and still do in my armpit and arm in certain areas. I also had severe pain in my arm at certain times but now I dont. The stretches and excercises really helped me. I hope you are well and I think you will find a lot of useful info here. Hugs to everyone pre and post surgery. Healing prayers coming your way.

I have bad back pain and 2 days ago I started having sharp pain radiating down my right arm. So my mo put me on neurontin today and is sending me to a neurologist. Gee great another copay.  Ugh... They also did an ultrasound on my axilla just to make sure there was no hematoma or anything. I only have 2 more treatments then I get to go to radiation. Nona I think my last tx will be Dec 4th. Yeah.  Trinity the claritin helps me with the general bone pain from the neulesta shot. The water is a big help too. Oh yeah and how could I forget the mouth sores/ dry mouth. I must have not chewed on enough ice this time. Popsicles usually help me with that but I forgot them this past time and only chewed regular ice. Who was it talking about the fat thing.... Beckers? Blessings? Well I want you to know that you cant possibly be as fat as I feel. lol. I have to keep telling myself that when we start to feel better with more energy we will be able to move more and lose this weight. I know we can. I hope everyone in the NorthEast US is ok and holding on. Prayers are sent your way and prayers to all of us Strong Beautiful Women that are se's are minimal and that are surgical sites are healed. Love to all of you.

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2012 09:36AM melmcbee wrote: Hi my name is Melanie. I am 42 and was dx at the end of June with ilc. I have spent the last 2 weeks on here learning about breast cancer.I work in the medical field and have realized that I know nothing about this. It didnt show up on my mammo in Dec. I felt a lump on Sunday and went to the breast center on thurs where the did mamo, us, and bx. I got the resultsand have already had a bmx on july 9th. There was a big tumor and 2 possible small one in the breast so a lumpectomy was out. Because this type doesnt show up well on mammo or us until its big I chose to go ahead and have both removed. I had tes put in and now im just waiting on mo to tell me the treatment plan.I dont knowwhat the tumor actually measure or if the other 2 were malignant or if its in my nodes or if there were any in my left breast. the mri showed the tumor at 5.6 cm. Im glad yall are here so I can ask questions. Thanks for being here. the shock is about gone and reality is setting in.

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2013 08:27PM melmcbee wrote: I am so sorry that you have to be here. There is a lot of support here and you are welcome. After my biopsy results I had a mri of both breast to see the extent of the tumor. A pet scan and CT scan to see if there was any metastesis anywhere. I met with my medical oncologist and my case was taken to tumor board to see what my best option was. My oncologist worked closely with my surgeon and the tumor board said I would need a mastectomy. It was suggested to me to take both breast off because I had invasive lobular. When it was decided to do a matectomy I met with a plastic surgeon who would be doing my reconstruction and he wanted to put tissue expanders in and do the reconstruction at a later date due to the possibility of having radiation. I had the bmx with tissue expander placement and they do whats called a sentinel node biopsy during the surgery. If the sentinel node comes back positive they then do an axillary dissection. Because mine was lobular cancer it showed up as negative at first. After surgery the final path report came back positive and so I had another surgery to remove my lymph nodes on that side and they also put the port in then. Results from the nodes being removed were 8 positive out of 15.  So after surgery I had chemo for 5 months then radiation for 6 weeks and I will get reconstruction in 3 more months when my skin heals from radiation. Whew that was a mouthful. It takes all the doctors working together to decide a plan. Some plastic surgeons like to put implants in before radiation some like to do it afterward. You need to consult a plastic surgeon for that info. You need a medical oncologist to help you come up with a plan and maybe take your case to tumor board. You may need pre surgery scans to see if it is anywhere else. Anyway  hugs to you and feel free to ask away. There are alot of great people here. Hugs

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2014 09:55PM melmcbee wrote: Nancy, Im so sorry that you are so upset. Please really don't go there yet especially when it was a technologist who said something. It is the technologist's job to get a medical history but under no circumstances should they say anything about seeing something and the reason they shouldn't say it is because they are not qualified to say it. I am a technologist and I see stuff all the time and I am wrong sometimes. Because I am not qualified to read anything. And neither is the tech who did your scan today. I always have to ask if there is a prior history of injury or cancer or other medical conditions and I make sure the patient knows that I am asking this for a history not because of anything that is seen on their images. Please don't let this bother you. Wait until a doctor reads that scan. I promise that tech is NOT qualified to see or say anything.

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2012 01:51AM melmcbee wrote: Cindee, I am so sorry that you were made to feel that way. Let me tell you how it works in my hospital.  (im a ct, mri and xray tech). Technologist are not allowed to give results because we are not doctors and it is illegal. However I know that they sometimes do, I also know of situations where they told the pt what they thought and it turned out to be wrong. Thats why its illegal. However if a radiologist sees something of importance or emergent he will call the doctor and if he cant get a hold of a doctor he will call you. A radiologist will not let something emergent go because then that could be a lawsuit on him. If you sign a medical release at any doctors office like a pcp for example then they can get the results. At our hospital we have a medical records dept that you can go to and pick up a copy of your own results. They may just require a picture id.  Im not sure what type of facility you had yours done at but most should have a medical records dept. Good luck to you and again I am sorry that tech made you feel uneasy. The u/s techs I work with, had they known you traveled that far and or your doctor was unavailable... they would have probably had you wait there for the reading or sent you out to lunch and have you come back to give the radiologist time to read it. Our radiologist wouldnt have agreed with the tech blowing the pt off and expect her to worry and wait. However unless a radiologist gives a technologist a verbal reading on an exam the technologist cannot legally give a reading on their own opinion. They could lose their license for that. I pray you are well and I would immediately call your pcp to get that report or the facility and ask what they need to get you a copy. They can fax a medical release to you and you fax it back with a copy of your license and they can fax you that report. After I got that report I would write a complaint to the supervisor of radiology that the tech knew your doctor was awy and how concerned and scared you were and didnt even give you any tips on how to get that report. My boss would have our arse... for that. If you have any other facilities to go to I would also tell the supervisor that they just lost your business and how much you spent to fly there.. oh the more I think about it the madder it makes me. Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2014 11:59PM melmcbee wrote: Hi Sandra. Im sorry that you are going thru this. I wanted to tell you some suggestions that helped me after my first surgery. I was told to lightly rub the skin area to help desensitize it and I thought it was crazy but I did it and it worked. So I always looked like a fool at work rubbing my tissue expanders and side. It did start to work. I also used ice packs all of the time. Then I had the exchange surgery and didn't have too many problems until I got sick with cellulitis and a bad cough and I cracked a rib on my radiated/alnd side and have had problems ever since. I had intercostal nerve blocks which lasted for 5 months then I got sick with the bad cough again and I think I reinjured the rib and the nerve pain about killed me. I got the nerve blocks 1 week ago and it has helped with the severity of the pain but if I cough or sneeze I still feel like its a broke rib. I was told today that I just have to heal. I can get these injections every 3 months if needed but im hoping it will just go away. Unfortunately, when we are hit with a diagnosis of breast cancer we don't have the option of asking what damage the treatments and surgeries will cause because a cracked rib or fried nerve is still better than cancer. Or so I am telling myself. lol. As someone who has gone thru this since July 2012 I can say to try PT and the lymphedema PT. Learn how to do the Lymphatic manual drainage because it could help you and certainly wont hurt you.  Dulcigirl is smart to send you to the Lymphedema thread because they are really smart about the subject. Try to desensitize the area by massaging it. I was told not to use ice but it helped me however I was going thru chemopause and could melt an icecube on my forehead. lol  Goodluck and healing hugs

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2013 01:04AM melmcbee wrote: Faithfully, I am a radiological technologists and when I found the lump I went to work and told my co workers about it nd they got our mamo tech to feel it and she got me in to our radiologist breasst clinic in Jackonville. I jut had a clear mammo six months ago but they did a mammo which didnt show anything so they sent me for an ultrasound and a radiologist came in and looked at it and told me to go eat lunch and come back in two hours and get a biopsy. I knew that day the results would be positive just by what she said. That was on a tuesday and saturday I went to the hospital I ork for and pulled my own pathology report. Invasive lobular grows flat like a trellis and therefore it i usually not detected early. I had a mri on my breast and it actually measured at arojnd six cms but the when I had a bilat mastecfomy it turned out to be three different tumors. I ended up having 8 out of 15 positive nodes with extravasation into the tissue. I did six months of chemo and bad to do radiation. I now take arimidex. We dont really say we are cured or cancer free we just say we are NED. No evidence of disease. There is an IBC thread on here. Have you read any of it or posted any questions to them. They can help you get some i sight. I dont know much about IBC but I know the fear and frustration you are feeling. I pray you get to the right place to get you some answers that you ned and please let us know how you are doing. We are praying for B9 results for you.
